title: 4AT (4 A's Test) for Delirium Screening
description: Rapid clinical test for delirium detection in elderly patients. Includes cognitive test items, also suitable as a quick test for cognitive impairment.

parameters.name: amt4_errors
parameters.description: Number of errors in AMT4 (age, date of birth, place, current year)

parameters.name: attention_months
parameters.description: Performance on attention test (months in reverse order)

parameters.name: acute_change
parameters.description: Presence of acute change or fluctuating course

ranges.description: No delirium or moderate-severe cognitive impairment
ranges.interpretation: Result suggests absence of delirium and absence of moderate to severe cognitive impairment. Continue clinical monitoring as indicated.

ranges.description: Possible cognitive impairment, but not delirium
ranges.interpretation: Result suggests cognitive impairment but not delirium. Evaluate causes of cognitive impairment and consider more detailed neuropsychological assessment.

Score ≥4 suggests possible delirium. This result is not diagnostic - the final diagnosis must be based on clinical judgment. Comprehensive mental assessment and investigation of reversible causes are recommended.

references: Bellelli G, Morandi A, Davis DH, et al. Validation of the 4AT, a new instrument for rapid delirium screening: a study in 234 hospitalised older people. Age Ageing. 2014;43(4):496-502.

Shenkin SD, Fox C, Godfrey M, et al. Delirium detection in older acute medical inpatients: a multicentre prospective comparative diagnostic test accuracy study of the 4AT and the confusion assessment method. BMC Med. 2019;17(1):138.
De J, Wand AP. Delirium Screening: A Systematic Review of Delirium Screening Tools in Hospitalized Patients. Gerontologist. 2015;55(6):1079-99.
formula: Sum of 4 components: Alertness (0 or 4) + AMT4 (0-2) + Attention (0-2) + Acute Change (0 or 4)
notes: Test takes less than 2 minutes to perform
Can be applied even when patients cannot fully participate in cognitive tests
Score ≥4 is suggestive but not diagnostic of delirium
Widely validated and recommended in international guidelines
Suitable for use in general wards, outside the ICU
